questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding mechanism of trauma except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Trauma mechanisms are broadly classified into:

  • Blunt trauma
  • Penetrating trauma
  • Combined (mixed) trauma (Option A ruled out)

Among these, blunt trauma is by far the most common mechanism, especially in road traffic accidents, falls, and sports-related injuries. Penetrating injuries are less common and are usually due to stab wounds, gunshot injuries, or impalement.

Blunt trauma can further be categorized as:

  • Direct: Injury at the point of contact (e.g., fractured rib from a blow to the chest)
  • Indirect: Injury occurs at a site distant from the point of impact (e.g., deceleration injury causing aortic rupture) (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: What is the radiation dose from a single full-body CT scan?
questions.solution:
Explanation:


A single whole-body CT (WBCT) scan delivers an effective radiation dose of approximately 12-16 millisieverts (mSv). This dose accounts for exposure to all major organ systems.

To contextualize:

  • 1 chest X-ray ≈ 0.1-0.2 mSv
  • A WBCT ≈ 76 chest X-rays in terms of radiation dose
  • It is equivalent to around 6 months of background radiation exposure from natural environmental sources

Even though this level is below the high-dose range associated with immediate health risks, epidemiological studies (e.g., data from atomic bomb survivors) have shown a statistically significant increase in the risk of solid tumors with doses in the 5-100 mSv range.

choices.text: Awareness of critical diagnostic time windows
Prioritizing life-threatening conditions during initial assessment
Early screening of high-risk patients before signs are clinically apparent

questions.text: Which of the following is an important principle in the assessment of trauma patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Core principles of trauma assessment include:

  • Knowledge of timelines for important diagnoses is essential: Life-threatening conditions like tension pneumothorax, massive hemothorax, cardiac tamponade, and epidural hematoma require rapid recognition and intervention to prevent death.
  • Initial assessment should focus on what kills first: The ABCDE approach (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure) is a structured method to prioritize life-saving steps in order of urgency. Immediate threats are always addressed first.
  • Screen high-risk patients before clinical signs appear: In trauma, delayed signs can be deadly. High-risk patients (e.g., elderly, coagulopathic, polytrauma) must be evaluated early, sometimes before clear signs emerge, as waiting may cost critical time for intervention.

questions.text: Identify the fourth stage from the philosophy of damage control orthopedics (DCO) or damage control surgery (DCS):
questions.solution:
Explanation:


The concept of damage control surgery (DCS) and damage control orthopedics (DCO) evolved to reduce physiological insult in severely injured patients. This strategy is particularly important in polytrauma where multiple surgical procedures may trigger overwhelming systemic inflammation and immune dysregulation (i.e., the "second hit" phenomenon).

The stages of DCO are:

  1. Resuscitation
  2. Hemorrhage control
  3. Decompression
  4. Decontamination
  5. Fracture splintage

questions.text: Which of the following criteria most supports the need for damage control surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

pH < 7.2 indicates severe metabolic acidosis and physiological instability, strongly supporting the need for damage control surgery over definitive repair.

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for a patient presenting with signs of multiple injuries?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Whole Body CT (WBCT) with IV contrast, typically covering the head to pelvis, is the gold standard imaging modality for patients presenting with signs or symptoms of multiple injuries or deranged physiology in trauma.

WBCT is fast, accurate, and provides detailed imaging of all major organ systems, allowing for early detection of life-threatening injuries and reducing the time to definitive care. It improves diagnostic accuracy and decision-making in polytrauma settings. However, WBCT is not recommended solely based on the mechanism of injury without corresponding clinical signs.

Explanation of other options:

Whole body MRI (Option B): MRI is time-consuming, not suitable for unstable or trauma patients, and lacks utility in acute trauma resuscitation. It is better reserved for specific soft tissue or spinal injuries after initial stabilization.

CT angiography (Option C): CTA is indicated for evaluating vascular injury (e.g., neck, aorta, extremities), but it is not sufficient alone in polytrauma cases where multiple systems are involved.

DSA (Digital Subtraction Angiography) (Option D): DSA is invasive and used selectively for therapeutic embolization or vascular mapping. It is not a primary imaging modality in acute polytrauma.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the primary survey in trauma are correct except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:


The primary survey (ABCDE approach) in trauma is aimed at identifying and managing immediate life-threatening conditions. Fluid resuscitation is a part of circulation management, but excessive use of intravenous crystalloids or colloids is discouraged in modern trauma protocols.

Excessive crystalloids can lead to:

  • Hemodilution
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hypothermia
  • Increased risk of ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome)

Damage Control Resuscitation (DCR) focuses on:

  • Restrictive fluid strategy
  • Early use of blood products (preferably warmed)
  • Permissive hypotension unless contraindicated (e.g., TBI)

Explanation of other options:

Options A, B & C are correct

All trauma patients should have their cervical spine immobilised (Option A):
Cervical spine protection is mandatory in all trauma patients with potential head or neck injuries until C-spine injury is ruled out, especially during airway management.

A pelvic binder should apply to all hemodynamically unstable patients (Option B):
In hemodynamically unstable patients with suspected pelvic fractures (especially blunt trauma), pelvic binders should be applied early to control bleeding, and not removed until pelvic injury is excluded.

Higher BP > 90 mmHg should be targeted if a head injury is suspected (Option C):
While permissive hypotension (SBP 70-90 mmHg) is acceptable in general trauma, a higher target (>90 mmHg) is required in patients with suspected traumatic brain injury (TBI) to maintain cerebral perfusion and prevent secondary brain injury.

questions.text: What is the optimal ratio of pRBC:FFP:Platelets recommended in a massive transfusion protocol for trauma patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation:


In the setting of massive transfusion for trauma, the goal is to replicate whole blood resuscitation by delivering a balanced ratio of blood components to restore both oxygen-carrying capacity and coagulation factors.

  • The recommended ratio in most modern massive transfusion protocols (MTPs) is 1:1:1 ratio of pRBC:FFP:Platelets. e., 1 unit Packed Red Cells (pRBC) : 1 unit Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) : 1 unit Platelet concentrate
  • This balanced approach improves outcomes by reducing the risk of coagulopathy, hypothermia, and acidosis - the components of the lethal triad in trauma.
  • Blood and blood products should be warmed prior to transfusion to prevent hypothermia. Crystalloids and colloids are not preferred for initial resuscitation in massive hemorrhage.

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding administration of tranexamic acid to a trauma patient except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Tranexamic acid (TXA) is an antifibrinolytic agent that inhibits the activation of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby reducing fibrinolysis and blood loss. In trauma care, early administration is key to maximizing survival benefit. Administration of TXA after 3 hours may be harmful.

Recommended administration in trauma patients:

  • Initial dose: 1 g intravenously over 10 minutes (Option A ruled out)
  • Maintenance dose: Further 1 g given over 8 hours (Option C ruled out)
  • Indication: Should be given to all trauma patients with or at risk of significant hemorrhage, including those with SBP <90 mmHg or pulse >110/min (Option D ruled out)
  • Critical timing: TXA is most effective when given within 3 hours of injury. Administration after 3 hours may be harmful.

Role of crystalloids is limited to small volumes to maintain BP until blood products are available

questions.text: All of the following statements are incorrect regarding management of severe hypovolemia except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the initial management of severe hypovolemia, crystalloids are used only in minimal volumes to maintain a target systolic blood pressure (permissive hypotension) until definitive hemostasis is achieved and blood products are available. Large-volume crystalloid infusion is avoided as it can dilute clotting factors, worsen coagulopathy, and increase bleeding.

Current recommendations:

  • Prioritize blood and blood products over crystalloids for resuscitation.
  • Use massive transfusion protocols with balanced ratios of PRBCs, plasma, and platelets. (e.g., 1:1:1 ratio of pRBC:FFP:Platelets)
  • Administer tranexamic acid early in trauma patients with suspected bleeding.

Explanation of other options:

Tranexamic acid does not affect the rate of mortality after trauma (Option A): Tranexamic acid reduces mortality if given within 3 hours of trauma in patients with significant bleeding or risk of hemorrhage (as per CRASH-2 trial).

Severely hypovolemic trauma patients should be resuscitated using only colloids (Option B): Colloids are not recommended as the primary resuscitation fluid in severe hypovolemia. Blood and blood products are preferred to restore oxygen-carrying capacity and correct coagulopathy.

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The motor component of the GCS, not the verbal response, is the most reliable predictor of outcomes after TBI.
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a widely used tool to assess a patient's level of consciousness in various settings, particularly after head injury. (Option A ruled out)

It is composed of three components:

  1. Best Eye Response (E): scored 1 to 4
  2. Best Verbal Response (V): scored 1 to 5
  3. Best Motor Response (M): scored 1 to 6 (Option C ruled out)

The total GCS score ranges from 3 (deep coma or death) to 15 (fully awake and alert). (Option B ruled out)

While all three components are important for assessing neurologic status, studies have shown that the motor component alone is the best predictor of outcome after traumatic brain injury (TBI) - not the verbal score.

questions.text: In the Injury Severity Score (ISS), which score categorizes an injury as a severe injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Injury Severity Score (ISS) > 25 is classified as severe injury.
The Injury Severity Score (ISS), introduced by Baker et al., is calculated by:

  1. Dividing the body into six regions:
    • Head & Neck
    • Face
    • Chest
    • Abdomen
    • Extremities (including pelvis)
    • External
  2. Assigning an Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) score (1-6) to the injury in each region.
  3. Selecting the three most severely injured regions.
  4. Squaring their AIS scores and summing them:
    ISS = (AIS1)2 + (AIS2)2 + (AIS3)2

ISS range: 1-75. If any AIS is 6 (unsurvivable injury), ISS is automatically 75.

questions.text: All of the following are components of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:


 The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a physiologic scoring system used to assess the severity of injury and guide triage decisions in trauma patients. It incorporates three parameters:

  1. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) - to assess neurological status
  2. Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP) - to assess perfusion/shock status
  3. Respiratory Rate (RR) - to assess respiratory function

Pulse rate is not part of RTS.

RTS assigns coded values (0-4) to each parameter and calculates a weighted score:

Scoring Formula:

RTS = (0.93×GCS score) + (0.73×SBP score) + (0.29×RR score)

Higher scores indicate better physiologic status.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first priority if you are performing a primary survey on a patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The first priority in the primary survey is to ensure a patent airway because adequate oxygenation is essential for survival. Efforts to restore cardiovascular integrity or circulatory volume will be ineffective unless oxygen is delivered to the blood.

  • In trauma patients, airway management must be performed simultaneously with cervical spine immobilization until spinal injury is excluded.
  • This immobilization is typically accomplished by applying a hard cervical collar or placing sandbags on both sides of the head, with the patient's forehead taped across the bags to a backboard.
  • Soft collars do not effectively immobilize the cervical spine.
  • For penetrating neck wounds, cervical collars are generally not recommended, as they provide no benefit and may interfere with the assessment and treatment of the injury.

Explanation of other options:

Ensuring adequate circulatory volume (Option A): Circulatory support is essential but secondary to securing the airway. Without oxygenation, circulatory efforts are futile.

Ensuring adequate cardiac output (Option C): Cardiac output depends on airway patency and oxygen delivery. Hence, airway takes precedence.

Ensuring patient is oriented to time, place, and person (Option D): Orientation is a neurological assessment done after stabilizing airway, breathing, and circulation.

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding REBOA except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion of the aorta (REBOA) is a damage control resuscitation technique used in severe non-compressible torso hemorrhage. It involves inserting a balloon catheter via the common femoral artery, advancing it into the aorta, and inflating it to temporarily occlude blood flow distal to the balloon. (Options A & B ruled out)

The balloon is positioned proximal to the site of bleeding, not distal, to minimize further blood loss and maintain perfusion to the heart and brain. (Option D ruled out)

Placement zones vary:

  • Zone I: Left subclavian to celiac artery (for intra-abdominal bleeding)
  • Zone III: Below the renal arteries to aortic bifurcation (for pelvic bleeding)

By occluding the aorta, REBOA shunts blood centrally, improving coronary and cerebral perfusion while buying time for definitive hemorrhage control in the operating room.

questions.text: Which one of the following signs differentiates simple pneumothorax from tension pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Both simple pneumothorax and tension pneumothorax share many clinical features such as tachypnea, decreased breath sounds, and possibly distended neck veins. The key distinguishing feature is hypotension, which occurs in tension pneumothorax due to impaired venous return from increased intrapleural pressure.

Tension pneumothorax should be presumed in any patient with respiratory distress + hypotension along with one or more of:

  • Tracheal deviation away from the affected side
  • Absent or markedly decreased breath sounds on the affected side
  • Subcutaneous emphysema on the affected side

Venous return obstruction can cause jugular venous distension, though in hypovolemic states neck veins may be flat.
Simple pneumothorax does not cause significant hemodynamic compromise unless it progresses to tension type.

questions.text: Each rib fracture causes approximately how much amount of blood loss?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Each rib fracture can result in ~100-200 mL of blood loss.

This may not be enough to cause hemodynamic instability on its own, but multiple rib fractures can lead to significant cumulative blood loss, especially when combined with other injuries

Approximate blood loss from other common fractures:

In trauma patients, it is essential to consider cumulative blood loss from multiple injuries, as no single fracture may explain the degree of shock, but the sum of injuries can be life-threatening. Uncontrolled bleeding from multiple skeletal injuries is a major cause of traumatic hypovolemic shock.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. Upon examination, he was found to be unconscious and a large bruise on the abdomen was noted. What would be the next step of management for this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In trauma management, following the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) protocol is essential for prioritizing life-saving interventions. The first priority is securing the airway with cervical spine protection to prevent hypoxia and aspiration, which are immediate threats to life. This corresponds to the"A"in the cABCDE approach:

  • c - Control of massive external hemorrhage
  • A - Airway with cervical spine protection
  • B - Breathing and ventilation
  • C - Circulation and haemorrhage control: apply a pelvic binder and do not remove until a pelvic fracture is excluded
  • D - Disability (neurological status)
  • E - Exposure (assess for other injuries)

After securing airway and breathing, a FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) is performed to quickly detect intra-abdominal bleeding or free fluid that may require urgent intervention. (Option D ruled out)

Immediate whole body CT is contraindicated before airway and hemodynamic stabilization due to risk of deterioration. Similarly, shifting the patient directly to the operation theater without proper assessment risks missing airway or breathing problems that need urgent attention. (Options B & C ruled out)

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding debridement and initial wound care in disaster surgery except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In disaster surgery, wounds are often grossly contaminated due to blast injuries, debris, and delayed medical attention. After thorough debridement, the standard practice is to leave the wound open and perform delayed primary closure once the risk of infection is minimized.

Primary closure in such wounds can trap bacteria and necrotic tissue, leading to severe infection or sepsis.

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding crush syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Crush syndrome results from prolonged compression of skeletal muscle (usually >4-6 hours), leading to muscle ischemia, necrosis, and systemic complications once reperfusion occurs. It is a triad of crush injury, rhabdomyolysis, and acute kidney injury - first described in the London Blitz.

Fasciotomy after prolonged entrapment (>12 hours) is contraindicated because the affected muscle is usually non-viable, and surgical decompression at this stage may:

  • Cause a massive release of myoglobin and potassium into the circulation
  • Increase the risk of sepsis due to infection of necrotic tissue

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged muscle compression → ischemia
  • Reperfusion injury when the casualty is rescued → release of myoglobin and vasoactive mediators into circulation (Option B ruled out)
  • Fluid sequestration in damaged muscle → hypovolemia, renal vasoconstriction, and ischemia
  • Myoglobinuria → tubular obstruction and acute renal failure (Option C ruled out)

Management principles:

  • Early aggressive IV fluid loading (1-1.5 L/hr saline) before extrication
  • Catheterization to monitor urine output
  • Mannitol-alkaline diuresis (urinary pH >6.5) up to 8 L/day once urine flow is established, to reduce myoglobin precipitation in tubules and protect kidneys (Option D ruled out)
  • Early fasciotomy if compartment syndrome is suspected before muscle death
  • Late fasciotomy (>12 hours) is contraindicated - increases myoglobin release and infection risk

questions.text: All of the following are components of the trauma triad of death except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The trauma triad of death describes the lethal cycle that can develop in severely injured trauma patients, leading to worsening physiology and high mortality. It consists of:

  • Acidosis - from hypoperfusion and anaerobic metabolism (Option A ruled out)
  • Coagulopathy - from consumption of clotting factors, dilution by resuscitation fluids, and acidosis (Option B ruled out)
  • Hypothermia- due to exposure, infusion of cold fluids, and shock (Option C ruled out)

Hypotension is not part of this triad, although it often coexists due to hemorrhagic shock.
